The Janssen (J&J) vaccine manufactured at a Emergent Biosolutions plant will fall short of the originally planned amount by 60mn doses  that will not receive clearance by the FDA and will be eliminated from deliveries worldwide.
The German Federal Ministry for Health so far expected 10.1mn doses of the single-shot Janssen vaccine in the second quarter of 2021 (April, May, June)), but received only 1.7mn of these doses and only 1.2mn doses have yet been administered.
It is unclear whether the Emergent incident will cause a total collapse of deliveries in Q2 2021 and beyond, but it already means that those 8.4mn doses outstanding will have to be replaced by about 17mn doses of any other (two-shot-regimen) vaccine, and potentially delays the federal German vaccination campaign by ONE MONTH on average (Berlin being in the mid field).

Even though the Delta (B.1.617.2) variant is still rare in Germany and accounts for only 2% to 3% of all positive tests under surveillance, it has been steadily growing over the past few weeks and, unlike the Beta (B.1.351) and Gamma (P.1) variants, which have almost disappeared now, is likely to stay and have a growing share.
Given its likely higher transmissibility (+60% versus Alpha (B.1.1.7)) and signs of higher likelihood of a severe illness and deadly outcome, and given the initial experience with the Alpha variant in the winter 2020/21, public administrations have raised the alarms somewhat. It is likely that given the low recent incidence figures (~20/100k population), lots of travel within Germany (mainly North to South, West to North) will spill over the current pockets of Delta/B.1.617.2 which are situated in Northrhine-Westfalia and Bavaria, throughout the country in a matter of week. UEFA 2020 Euro Championships will bring in additional international travel, even though only Munich (Bavaria) serves as a host city. However, Hessia, with FRA as one of Europe's busiest airports, has found an above-average number of Delta, and the pick-up in international travel for summer holidays along with travel to and from sporting events, appear to be a unhealthy cocktail. Delta has even arrived in Berlin and some counties on Berlin's fringes and some other East German cities such as Dresden (Saxony). Watching football matches in crowded bars (even if largely outdoors), among neighbors and friends could prove to be prone to fresh outbreaks. In all, it seems set that the share of Delta will follow the pattern of the UK (where Delta has become the "dominant strain" already) and increase even in Germany to more than 10% of all cases by end of June.
Given the recently slow progress in vaccinations amid repeated scarcity of vials, a "summer effect" (reduced viral lifetime of ~20%) that cannot compensate for Delta's higher r0 and people partying in the streets like it's 2019 and being more careless amid fast reopenings, I'm increasingly worried that Germany's fourth wave of SARS-CoV-2 is going to arrive sooner than expected: Germany may have 10k+ cases per day in July already. With incoming tourist from the EU, Berlin may indeed prove to be at the center of the problem. A long story cut short, here's what the Humboldt Forum organizers say:
"Ausblick Sofern sich die Pandemie-Lage weiterhin stabilisiert, werden im Juli die Ausstellungen im Erdgeschoss und 1. Obergeschoss (Geschichte des Ortes, Einblicke. Die Brüder Humboldt, schrecklich schön. Elefant – Mensch – Elfenbein, Nimm Platz! Eine Ausstellung für Kinder, Nach der Natur und BERLIN GLOBAL) öffnen. Im Spätsommer 2021 folgen der Westflügel der zweiten und dritten Etage mit dem Ethnologischen und Asiatischen Museum sowie die Dachterrasse. In der ersten Jahreshälfte 2022 schließlich steht den Besucher*innen das gesamte Haus offen."
https://www.humboldtforum.org/de/besuch-vor-ort/ (No official translation under https://www.humboldtforum.org/en/on-location/ , but it says "Under the assumption that the pandemic situation continues to stabilize, exhibitions in the basement and on the 2nd floor (Geschichte des Ortes, Einblicke. Die Brüder Humboldt, schrecklich schön. Elefant – Mensch – Elfenbein, Nimm Platz! Eine Ausstellung für Kinder, Nach der Natur und BERLIN GLOBAL) will open in July." My assumption is they are going to use June/July's deteriorating situation and the scary outlook for August to postpone the opening into fall (when everybody has been able to get vaccinated and exhibitions (and the city as a whole) will be less crowded by tourists), while the real reason behind may be the mounting pressure from deadlines to trouble-shoot the shortcomings of the building. Their own wording is more cautious and less optimistic than what was purported by the media. Finally, the strange news about the Humboldt Foundation's treatment of staff may make it harder for them to fill vacancies. For example, the foundation is still hiring an "IT-Enterprise Architekt*in (m/w/d)" (closing date 25 June 2021, https://www.humboldtforum.org/de/jobs/ ), whose likely task it is to streamline the purportedly fragmented and unsafe software environment which appears to cause a lion share of the trouble within the building (lighting, electricity, dysfunctional doors, box offices, air conditioning,...).
If they do find and hire key staff by the end of June, I only wonder just how much a single person can improve a system in a matter of two to four weeks that has been corrupted by dozens of contractors over several months...

The German parliament is currently discussing the federal emergency brake mechanism ("Bundesnotbremse") and will likely vote to accept it later today against the votes of AfD, Die Linke MP's.
The current version of the law, which has been fast-tracked amid a surge of infections in April, currently contains no exception for people fully vaccinate with respect to applicability. However, for certain situations being fully vaccinated may lead to an exemption from testing obligations. A court recently dismissed a law suit of two fully vaccinated individuals against the rules of the city of Gießen (Hessia), which among others contain curfews at night. The court decision, which could be a landmark case in this respect, said that there is too little scientific evidence of "sterilizing immunity" (inability to infect others) achieved through full vaccination, so that all rules still do apply for these two individuals, despite being fully vaccinated.
This makes it harder for publicly owned museums to have preferred entry for the vaccinated, or any other concepts that eases hygiene measures in public spaces.
Museums could be forced to remain closed until the status of assumed herd immunity in Germany and/or Berlin will be achieved, as a consequence.

Berlins senate's decision of today mostly concerned the opening of schools after the Easter break, which is of high priority.
https://www.berlin.de/sen/bjf/service/presse/pressearchiv-2021/pressemitteilung.1073249.php All plans for re-opening  as of mid-March footed on the assumption of a further decline in cases per 7 days per 100k inhabitants to well below 50.
Plans were also based on scientific and technical advice published by the federal German environmental protection agency Umweltbundesamt (UBA), which deems a reopening of theaters, concerts, movie theaters and other rather long-lasting static events at which people are seated to be safe if certain conditions are met AND the above mentioned important threshold of 50 (cases per 7 days per 100k inhabitants) or lower is kept. For cases with a higher actual figure, there is no advice given in the recommendation, since then other aspects and considerations such as the situation the hospitals' ICUs would be crucial.
https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/bundesregierung/staatsministerin-fuer-kultur-und-medien/aktuelles/experten-legen-eckpunkte-zur-wiederoeffnung-von-theatern-kinos-und-bibliotheken-vor-kulturstaatsministerin-gruetters-verantwortungsvoller-neustart-ist-moeglich--1872466
https://www.umweltbundesamt.de/sites/default/files/medien/421/dokumente/moriske_et._al._eckpunkte_zur_durchfuehrung_von_kulturveranstaltungen_-_theater_konzerthaeuser_kinos_-_unter_pandemiebedingungen_3.3.2021.pdf
Although museums and libraries are considered slightly less problematic with regards to aerosols due to dynamics/movements in restricted visitors numbers, problems could still arise from crowded situation and groupings of people. Berlin, similar to Germany as a whole (currently at ~110), has a value of 130 cases per 7 days per 100k inhabitants, and this with the expectation of lower than actual figures due to disruptions in testing and reporting during holidays.
Last time Germany was in a similar situation at the beginning of the second wave was around 15 October 2020, and it took three months until 15 January 2021 after a peak around Christmas that Germany has reduced the average figure back to the initial level. This time, with more knowledge about Variants of Concern and their potential effect on infection chains, it will likely take even longer to get near the value of 50, which results in mid-July 2021. Thus what determines the perspectives for openings of museums most will be the situation in high care units of hospitals, for which there exists a nationwide database that delivers an overview about occupied and spare capacities, hosted by the medical association called DIVI e.V.
https://www.divi.de/
https://www.divi.de/register/tagesreport Two of the most influential voices of the medical community have issued a call for immediate action and for emergency measures in order to prevent hospitals from being overwhelmed in the first week of May.
Projections show that even under the optimistic scenario for vaccinations the society will likely have to accept a stricter lockdown than ever before, and the longer it takes for decision-makers to come to the same conclusion, the tougher the measures will have to be and the longer it will take until hospitals will return to normal conditions again, on average by 01 July 2021.
https://twitter.com/ECMOKaragianni1/status/1379754846702743553 (head of DIVI e.V.)
https://twitter.com/c_drosten/status/1380058204927885314 (advisor to the federal government) Even if all things go well and hospitals in Germany experience a mild, managable scenario, a trade-off will remain between inevitable mobility and contacts (schools, essential economic activity) and non-essential sectors such as museums.
I thus assume that the beginning of holidays could be prove crucial for other sectors to open during summer vacation. For Berlin, this would mean 24 June 2021 as of now, but then again I'm not sure these dates won't be subject to change this year.
Teachers (about 1mn employees) will have to be fully vaccinated first, before school opening really is more or less safe, and vacations may this year be coordinated with lock downs, but this is rather speculative.
In any case and in any scenario, it's fairly certain that the education sector will have a higher priority than museums until immunization through the vaccination program nears herd immunity. EDIT:

This question is rather complex, like the historic grounds the Humboldt Forum is buildt upon are overly complex, too. On the surface, the regulation is very easy:
The Humboldt Forum is characterized as a "cosmopolitan forum for culture, art and science", but first and foremost it is supposed to host the vast collections of several museums in and around Berlin, and a museum with exhibitions of pieces of these collections. It is meant to form an emsemble together with a few more reknowned, important museums on the "Museumsinsel" in the historic city center of Berlin: 
Altes Museum (Old Museum), Neues Museum (New Museum), Alte Nationalgalerie (Old National Gallery), Bode Museum, Pergamon Museum and finally the newly reconstruced city castle-shaped Humbolt Forum, which together as a whole "was added to the UNESCO list of World Heritage Sites" in 1999. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_Island
The name, by the way, refers to the Humboldt brothers, who were important advisers to the kings of Prussia in the late 18th and early 19th century and, being researchers themselves, laid the foundation of the Prussian and later German higher education system with a focus on humanism as it is known today.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_von_Humboldt
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_von_Humboldt As a museum located in Berlin (irrespective of ownership or users), disease prevention in Berlin is under the rule of the city (and land) Berlin, which currently states:
"Nach ersten Öffnungen Mitte des Monats lassen die Staatliche Museen in Berlin die Türen weiterer Häuser geschlossen.
Zunächst sollen die neuen Regelungen mit obligatorischen Corona-Tests in den bereits geöffneten Museen getestet werden, hieß es am Mittwoch (31. März 2021) zur Begründung.

Im ersten Schritt waren neben dem Neuen Museum mit der berühmten Nofretete die Alte Nationalgalerie, die James-Simon-Galerie, das Pergamonmuseum und das Panorama auf der Museumsinsel Berlin sowie das Museum Europäischer Kulturen in Dahlem geöffnet worden. Weitere Häuser sollten eigentlich an diesem Donnerstag folgen. Das ist nun ausgesetzt.

https://www.berlin.de/ausstellungen/nachrichten/6492485-3041403-staatliche-museen-in-berlin-verschieben-.html
Amid the infection rates in Germany and in Berlin, the scheduled reopening after 16 March 2021 has been halted on 31 March and re-defined as a "trial" for visits to museums and other public spaces under strict testing regimes, which will now end on 07 April for the time being. In general, Berlin's "Infektionsschutzverordnung" (infection protection act) is due to run out on 18 April 2021, and will likely be renewed and prolonged for four more weeks in a "Conference of decision makers" of Bund and laender in the week before 10-17 April 2021, despite some criticism of this format and its outcomes. As a host to the federal government and with its nearly 3.5mn inhabitants, (the city and land) Berlin is of great importance and has a signalling function within the country. It is also a hotspot for international tourism and rather densely populated, so that disease control is a rather difficult task in Berlin, and rules are supposed to be rather strict in the near future.
From this perspective, an opening to the general public is rather unlikely before end of May 2021. For the months of June and July 2021, a seasonal effect could suppress the virus somewhat, so that there will be a permanent pressure in the public opinion for more "freedoms", and museums will argue for opening to the public with their budget, the loss in revenue and the fact that alternative routes for infections, such as international travel within the EU, are still allowed. However, being situated very close to Poland and rather close to Czechia, two countries in which the pandemic is mostly out of control due to mutant viruses, and with respect to frequent work commuting between the countries, mostly into Germany's eastern part due to the relatively higher wages, the pandemic and possibly future Variants of Concern (VoC) will be imported to Brandenburg (the land that surrounds Berlin) and Berlin very early and despite all testing efforts at the border. Museums and other cultural sites have a hard time to find a critical argument for why an opening now is "necessary", and the Humboldt Forum and e.g. the Louvre in Paris have brought up digital exhibition concepts in order to keep their relevance. In a situation, in which person-to-person contacts and mobility "in sum" pose a problem, in-person experience and visits of museum exhibitions are likely on the upper fringe of what the society can abstain from for a while. There are currently nine exhibitions on schedule for "Spring 2021", but this schedule may only be indicative at this point and subject to changes, as the pandemic proceeds, at the moment the Humboldt Forum and all others of the "Staatliche Museen zu Berlin" (15 in total) will remain closed after the "trial" ends on 07 April for the foreseeable future and "until further notice". Right next to the Humboldt Forum the memorial "Denkmal für Freiheit und Einheit" is now under construction, and it already missed the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall for a scheduled inauguration due to a host of delays and issues. Possible symbolic dates for an inauguration would be 03 October 2021 or 09 November 2021, if construction is to be finished by then. I can imagine that, due to a symbolic value the city castle has as well (from the balcony of the historic city castle, the first German republic, the "Weimar republic", and thus democracy, was proclaimed in 1918), there will be a wish by politicians, local and federal, of all parties, to release the Humboldt Forum from the pressure to open to the public soon, and to open both of the sites together and hand them to the public in one large symbolic act on one of the dates in autumn 2021. Everything else could look smallish and inappropriate amid the cost of currently 682mn EUR for the Humboldt Forum alone.
